title: Greetings and Basic Politeness
goal: Learn essential greetings and polite expressions for daily interactions
objectives: Greet people appropriately at different times of day
Use basic politeness expressions (thank you, excuse me, sorry)
Understand when to use Taiwanese vs. Mandarin in social contexts

vocabulary.notes: Less commonly used than morning/evening greetings
Used for both greeting and goodbye at night
Most common way to say thanks

vocabulary.pinyin: nǐ jiào shén me míng zi?

grammar.title: 是 (sī) structure - Identity and Classification
grammar.explanation: 是 (sī) is used to state identity, occupation, or classification. It's equivalent to 'to be' in English when linking a subject to a noun.

grammar.title: 的 (ê) possessive particle
grammar.explanation: 的 (ê) shows possession or relationship between nouns. It's similar to 's or 'of' in English.
grammar.notes: 的 (ê) can sometimes be omitted in casual speech, especially with close relationships (e.g., 我媽 instead of 我的媽 for 'my mom').

grammar.title: 未 (buē/bē) question particle - Yes/No Questions
grammar.explanation: 未 (buē/bē) is placed at the end of statements to form yes/no questions. It's similar to adding '...yet?' or '...or not?' in English.

grammar.title: 呢 (neh) - 'And you?' / 'What about...?'
grammar.explanation: 呢 (neh) is used to return a question or ask about someone/something else. It's like saying 'and you?' or 'what about...?'

grammar.title: 嘛 (mā) - 'Also' / 'Too'
grammar.explanation: 嘛 (mā) means 'also' or 'too'. It's placed after the subject or before the verb.

culturalNotes.title: Traditional Greeting - 食飽未?
culturalNotes.content: "食飽未?" (Have you eaten?) is a traditional greeting that reflects Taiwan's agricultural past when food security was a real concern. Today, it's used to show care and concern, not as a literal question. The appropriate response is simply "食飽矣" (I've eaten) even if you haven't!

culturalNotes.title: When to Use Taiwanese
culturalNotes.content: Taiwanese is commonly used among older generations, in traditional markets, temples, and in southern Taiwan (especially Tainan and Kaohsiung). Using Taiwanese shows respect and cultural connection. Many younger Taiwanese are learning it to connect with their heritage.

culturalNotes.title: Code-Switching is Natural
culturalNotes.content: Don't worry about mixing Taiwanese and Mandarin - it's very common and completely natural! Many Taiwanese people seamlessly switch between languages within a single conversation. This is called 'code-switching' and is a normal part of bilingual communication.

culturalNotes.title: Politeness Levels
culturalNotes.content: Taiwanese has different levels of politeness, though not as formal as some languages. Adding 請 (tshiánn - please) before requests and using 您 (lín) instead of 你 (lí) for 'you' shows extra respect to elders or superiors.

culturalNotes.title: Name Customs
culturalNotes.content: In Taiwanese culture, it's common to use 阿 (A-) before someone's given name as a friendly, informal way to address them (like A-Ming 阿明). This is more casual than using full names but warmer than surnames.

exercises.title: Choose the Correct Response
exercises.instructions: Select the most appropriate Taiwanese response

items.question: Someone says 'Lí-hó' to you. How do you respond?
items.explanation: 你好 (Lí-hó) is the appropriate greeting response. 再會 means goodbye, and 歹勢 means sorry.

items.question: You accidentally bump into someone. What should you say?
items.explanation: 歹勢 (Pháinn-sè) means 'sorry' and is used for apologizing.

items.question: It's 7:00 AM and you meet your neighbor. What greeting is most appropriate?
items.explanation: 𠢕早 (Gâu-tsá) means 'good morning' and is used in the morning hours.
